title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What is the fundamental counting principle in probability?

options.label: A
options.text: The probability of an event is always 1/2.

options.label: B
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A times B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: C
options.text: The probability of getting a question right by guessing is always 1/5.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of possible outcomes is always 2 to the power of the number of questions.

multiple-choice.question: A 10-question true/false quiz has how many possible combinations of answers?
What is the probability of getting a perfect score by guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
If you and your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 10-question true/false quiz, what would be the expected average score in the long run?
How do you find the average number of questions you would get right by guessing on a true/false quiz?

options.label: A
options.text: Multiply the number of questions by the probability of getting the question wrong.

options.label: B
options.text: Multiply the number of questions by the probability of getting the question right.

options.label: C
options.text: Add the number of questions to the probability of getting the question right.

options.label: D
options.text: Subtract the number of questions from the probability of getting the question right.

multiple-choice.question: If there are 20 questions on a multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question, what is the probability of getting a question right by guessing?
On a 20-question multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question, how many questions would you expect to get right by guessing?
What is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing on a multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 in 1 million

options.label: B
options.text: 1 in 10 million

options.label: C
options.text: 1 in 95 trillion

options.label: D
options.text: 1 in 100 trillion

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason casinos and lotteries remain in business?

options.label: A
options.text: Because people are lucky.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the odds are in favor of the house.

options.label: C
options.text: Because people have a lot of money to spend.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the games are entertaining.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it generally not a good idea to guess on a true/false quiz?

options.label: A
options.text: Because you might get some questions wrong.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the probability of getting a perfect score is very low, and guessing does not provide a reliable way to achieve a good score.

options.label: C
options.text: Because you might run out of time.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's not a strategic approach to taking a quiz.

multiple-choice.question: What type of narrative is described as the "glue that connects people" in journalism, making the personal universal and timeless?

options.label: A
options.text: Investigative narrative

options.label: B
options.text: Authentic narrative

options.label: C
options.text: Expository narrative

options.label: D
options.text: Descriptive narrative

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what are the three essential components of sourcing required in every well-reported piece of journalism, forming a trifecta?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, social media, and eyewitness accounts

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

options.label: C
options.text: Academic sources, expert opinions, and statistical data

options.label: D
options.text: Government reports, press releases, and public records

multiple-choice.question: Which type of source is most likely to provide insight into the personal impact of an event or trend, giving consequence and meaning on a soul level?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources

options.label: B
options.text: Overview sources

options.label: C
options.text: Unofficial sources

options.label: D
options.text: Academic sources

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of asking surprising questions in journalism, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To gather factual information quickly

options.label: B
options.text: To create a sensationalized headline

options.label: C
options.text: To establish a deeper connection with the subject and uncover compelling insights

options.label: D
options.text: To provoke a reaction from the interviewee

multiple-choice.question: In what type of situation is it more important to prioritize conveying information quickly over narrative storytelling, such as presenting bulleted facts and updates?

options.label: A
options.text: When writing a feature article

options.label: B
options.text: When reporting on a breaking news event or in an emergency situation

options.label: C
options.text: When conducting an in-depth interview

options.label: D
options.text: When writing a blog post

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what role do anecdotes play in storytelling, particularly in making a story more relatable?

options.label: A
options.text: Providing additional facts and data

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a distraction from the main point

options.label: C
options.text: Breathing life into a story and making it more relatable

options.label: D
options.text: Summarizing the main points of the story

multiple-choice.question: How do journalists make personal stories relatable to a wider audience, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: By focusing on the individual's specific experiences

options.label: B
options.text: By using sensationalized language

options.label: C
options.text: By making the story timeless, humanistic, and universal

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the bigger picture

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of using the "artful solicitation of story" in journalism, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The journalism becomes more sensationalized

options.label: B
options.text: The journalism becomes more memorable and creates a narrative bond with the audience

options.label: C
options.text: The journalism becomes more factual

options.label: D
options.text: The journalism becomes more superficial

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the benefit of treating every subject's story with respect and care, regarding their stories as sacred?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the journalist to ask more aggressive questions

options.label: B
options.text: It helps the journalist to create a more sensationalized headline

options.label: C
options.text: It enables the journalist to establish a deeper connection with the subject and uncover compelling insights

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the journalist more objective

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of using narrative personal stories in journalism, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To convey information quickly

options.label: B
options.text: To create a sense of urgency

options.label: C
options.text: To create a connection between people and make the story more relatable

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a summary of the main points

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: Who said that "There is no frigate like a book to take us lands away..."?

options.label: A
options.text: Jane Austen

options.label: B
options.text: Emily Dickinson

options.label: C
options.text: Samuel Richardson

options.label: D
options.text: Mark Twain

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens when we "land" after being carried away by a story?

options.label: A
options.text: We retrace the footsteps of the authors or characters.

options.label: B
options.text: We walk a mile in their shoes.

options.label: C
options.text: We forget what we read.

options.label: D
options.text: We become the authors or characters.

multiple-choice.question: Researchers in psychology, neuroscience, child development, and biology are studying the impact of stories on which aspect of human culture?

options.label: A
options.text: Economic trends

options.label: B
options.text: Ideas of class, marriage, and gender

options.label: C
options.text: Environmental policies

options.label: D
options.text: Educational outcomes

multiple-choice.question: What was significant about Samuel Richardson's novel "Pamela" when it was first published?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a bestseller, but didn't challenge any traditions.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a romance novel that reinforced societal norms.

options.label: C
options.text: It caused a ruckus and challenged several traditions.

options.label: D
options.text: It was the first novel to feature a female protagonist.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what might be a limitation of Darwin's theory of evolution?

options.label: A
options.text: It doesn't account for the role of intelligence in evolution.

options.label: B
options.text: It doesn't consider the impact of stories on our understanding of evolution.

options.label: C
options.text: It might not be the whole story, and our sense of being a hero might be wrong.

options.label: D
options.text: It only applies to humans, not other species.

multiple-choice.question: What does the author suggest we should do when reading classic literature?

options.label: A
options.text: Only read classic literature.

options.label: B
options.text: Only read modern literature.

options.label: C
options.text: Consider the changing world and its impact on our understanding of stories.

options.label: D
options.text: Be cautious of the influence of stories on our worldview.

multiple-choice.question: Which novel is mentioned as a potential influence on our thinking about capitalism?

options.label: A
options.text: "Pride and Prejudice"

options.label: B
options.text: "The Hunger Games"

options.label: C
options.text: "Uglies"

options.label: D
options.text: "Jane Eyre"

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what might "Uglies" reflect?

options.label: A
options.text: The dangers of pursuing a perfect body and letting the media define what is beautiful.

options.label: B
options.text: The importance of individualism over group cohesion.

options.label: C
options.text: The benefits of a capitalist society.

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of social media on relationships.

multiple-choice.question: What does the author suggest about the availability of new stories?

options.label: A
options.text: There are no new stories being written.

options.label: B
options.text: Only classic literature is worth reading.

options.label: C
options.text: There are always new stories being written, and they can influence and spark change.

options.label: D
options.text: New stories are not as valuable as classic literature.

multiple-choice.question: What is the final question posed by the author?

options.label: A
options.text: What is the most important story of all time?

options.label: B
options.text: What story will you try on next?

options.label: C
options.text: Why are stories important?

options.label: D
options.text: How can we use stories to shape our worldview?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of using logarithms in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: To simplify complex algebraic equations

options.label: B
options.text: To deal with extremely small or large numbers

options.label: C
options.text: To solve geometric problems

options.label: D
options.text: To calculate statistical probabilities

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the base number, b, and the logarithm, p, in an exponential equation?

options.label: A
options.text: b = p

options.label: B
options.text: b^p = n

options.label: C
options.text: p = log base b of n

options.label: D
options.text: b = log base p of n

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of log base 10 of 10,000?
Why is log base 10 commonly used in scientific calculations?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is easy to calculate

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has its own button on most calculators

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is used in computer science

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is used in chemistry

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of log base 2 of 64?
What is the formula for calculating the pH of a water sample?

options.label: A
options.text: pH = log base 10 of H+

options.label: B
options.text: pH = -log base 10 of H+

options.label: C
options.text: pH = log base 2 of H+

options.label: D
options.text: pH = -log base 2 of H+

multiple-choice.question: Why do swimming pools with a pH of 8.4 cause eye irritation?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the pH is too acidic

options.label: B
options.text: Because the pH is too basic

options.label: C
options.text: Because the pH is equal to the pH of tears

options.label: D
options.text: Because the pH is not calculated correctly

How can logarithms be used to simplify calculations involving extremely small or large numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: By using exponents instead of logarithms

options.label: B
options.text: By using logarithms to reduce the number of digits

options.label: C
options.text: By using logarithms to increase the number of digits

options.label: D
options.text: By using logarithms to calculate statistical probabilities

multiple-choice.question: What is a real-world application of logarithms in chemistry?

options.label: A
options.text: Calculating the boiling point of water

options.label: B
options.text: Calculating the pH of water samples

options.label: C
options.text: Calculating the density of a substance

options.label: D
options.text: Calculating the melting point of a substance

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What was the first known device used to tell time, dating back nearly 5,000 years?

options.label: A
options.text: Mechanical clock

options.label: B
options.text: Sundial

options.label: C
options.text: Hourglass

options.label: D
options.text: Water clock

multiple-choice.question: What is a significant limitation of using sundials as a time-telling device?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not accurate during the day

options.label: B
options.text: They require frequent adjustments

options.label: C
options.text: They don't work during the night or in cloudy conditions

options.label: D
options.text: They are only useful for short periods

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the gnomon in a sundial?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure the passage of time

options.label: B
options.text: To cast a shadow onto a surface

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the temperature

options.label: D
options.text: To indicate the direction

multiple-choice.question: Why was the hourglass a practical time-measuring device for use on board ships?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was compact and lightweight

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was inexpensive and easy to use

options.label: C
options.text: Because the motion of the boat did not affect its accuracy

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was a traditional navigation tool

multiple-choice.question: What innovation in the 13th century revolutionized traditional timekeeping methods?

options.label: A
options.text: The invention of the sundial

options.label: B
options.text: The development of the hourglass

options.label: C
options.text: The creation of the mechanical clock

options.label: D
options.text: The introduction of the atomic clock

multiple-choice.question: Why is it crucial to keep track of time in modern society?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate daily routines and schedules

options.label: B
options.text: To facilitate global communication and coordination

options.label: C
options.text: To ensure uniform standard times across regions

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What are some potential challenges that a society might face without a standardized time system?

options.label: A
options.text: Difficulties in farming and social structures

options.label: B
options.text: Inefficiencies in communication and business

options.label: C
options.text: Problems with transportation and education

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What issue arose in the mid-19th century due to the use of different time standards by railroads?

options.label: A
options.text: Trains were frequently delayed or early

options.label: B
options.text: There were accidents caused by time differences

options.label: C
options.text: Major railroad junctions experienced confusion and scheduling conflicts

options.label: D
options.text: Passengers had difficulty keeping track of schedules

multiple-choice.question: How do time zones contribute to smoother global communication and coordination?

options.label: A
options.text: By establishing a single, universal time standard

options.label: B
options.text: By eliminating the need for time zones

options.label: C
options.text: By reducing the number of time zones

options.label: D
options.text: By creating uniform standard times within regions

multiple-choice.question: Why are there 40 time zones on land, despite the Earth having 24 hours in a day?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Earth is divided into 40 distinct regions

options.label: B
options.text: Because each country has its own unique time zone

options.label: C
options.text: Because the earliest and latest time zones are 26 hours apart

options.label: D
options.text: Because some countries span multiple time zones
